message_1: In a class of 30 students, how many ways can you choose a group of 5 students to form a study group?
message_2:
To find the number of ways to choose a group of 5 students from a class of 30, we use the combination formula, which is:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of students (30 in this case), k is the number of students we want to choose (5), and ! denotes the factorial function (e.g., 5! = 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1).

So, we have:

C(30, 5) = 30! / (5!(30-5)!)

C(30, 5) = 30! / (5!25!)

C(30, 5) = (30 × 29 × 28 × 27 × 26 × 25!)/(5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1 × 25!)

The 25! in the numerator and denominator cancel each other out:

C(30, 5) = (30 × 29 × 28 × 27 × 26)/(5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1)

Now, we can simplify the expression:

C(30, 5) = (30 × 29 × 28 × 27 × 26)/(120)

C(30, 5) = 142506

So, there are 142,506 ways to choose a group of 5 students from a class of 30.
